Mr. H. Brooking
Assistant Provincial Archivist
Saskatoon, Sask.

Dear Sir,

I was very pleased to receive your letter of Dec. 6th replying to mine sent to Mr. Allan R. Turner, Regina. I may say I consider it a very pleasant privilege to be requested to supply an account of my experiences in the early history of Saskatchewan. I hope my account may be of some value.

Briefly I would like to explain that those experiences could be divided into two or three distinct parts or periods:

The first of these periods would be from 1903, working at various pioneer jobs on building roads & railroads constructed & homesteaded in the Cut Knife country. I served three years in the World War & afterward took a soldier grant of land in the Peaceful River Settlement south of Prairie River 11/2 miles, and farmed there until retiring a few years ago.

This venture was not an easy one the land was
In my early years, there were no roads or streams here. We took a severe freeze in the winter, but the drought year 1919 caused it to turn up. We endured the hardship of travel, but most of us liked myself were so glad to be back from the war that we were willing to face up to difficulties which we could only guess at.

However, we (my wife & I) the family did our best to gradually build a successful farm, and our sons now farm here & our daughters have their homes not too far from us.

Still it is right, the early experiences of the early years here should be made available for future generations & students, it will be a pleasure if seen help towards this end.

I have filled in the questionnaire you sent me though rather sketchily.

I would chiefly like to record my early experiences especially those building the Canadian Northern Railway from Battleford to Edmonton in the year 1905. There were many events that were the world recording & my memories are nearly as clear as when they took place, especially I think of some of the very outstanding resourceful men I got to know and the conditions...
Very hard, there were no roads & swamps here took a severe toll of the horses through the year 1919 caused it to turn up (induced) me to move & did not realize the hardship of travel from country but most of us like myself were so glad to be back from the war that we were willing to face up to difficulties which we could only guess at.

However we (my wife & the family) did our best & gradually build a successful farm, any our sons now farm here & our daughters have their homes not too far from us.

Still it is right that early experiences of the early years here should be made available for future generations & students it will be a pleasure if you help towards this end.

I have tried in the questionnaire you sent me though rather sketchily.

I would chiefly like to record my early experiences especially those building the Canadian Northern Railway from Battleford to Edmonton in the year 1905 there were many events that will be worth recording & my memories are nearly as clear as when they took place, especially I think of some of the very outstanding resourceful men I got to know & the conditions
I hope apart from this introductory letter to give a brief account of that work, it was very dangerous & always with great hardship. Here were 40 old men on our outfit mostly young like myself 21 years & needing to earn to get a little start in life.

The work was the teamsters' labor in the ties behind us was the steel laying crew - about 150 men, all had to be physically strong & resourceful, we worked in all weather & slept on the ground in tents at night.

Work problems arose very frequently & the work manager (Brown) had to be extremely resourceful and hardy but they were like able men & we respected & admired them for their qualities.

If I shall be able to give you a fairly good account of these experiences into answer as well as possible any questions you might like answered.

Hoping to be of service to you,

Your Sincerely

The building of Canada's second transcontinental railway, the Canadian Northern Railway, was conceived and built in the winter hundreds years by the Hon. Sir William J. Ross, Prime Minister and Sir Donald Macdonald who also served as its contractors, and it was reported that they gained a fortune in this double role.

In the early spring of 1905 the end of steel was approached at the divisional point that became the city of North Battleford and the Saskatchewan River crossing eight miles to the west where crews were preparing for the construction of the bridge to cross the river.

During the summer of 1904, grade had been built as far as Edmonton and during 1905 from May until mid-December the steel was laid to that point.

This required the co-operation of several large crews of men serving the different requirements; a temporary pile and timber bridge was built across the river and temporary material cranes, and track laying operations commenced on the south side of the river.

The track laying crew included a 200-man crew organized to handle the steel rails from the Peterborough yard and shipped on the trestle.

The building of Canada's second transcontinental railway, the Canadian Northern Railway, was conceived and built in the winter hundreds' years by the Hon. Sir William J. Ross (Sir Donald Macdonald) who also served as its contractor, and it was reported they gained fabulous riches, acting in the double role.

In the early spring of 1905 the end of steel was approaching the divisional point that became the city of Prince Albert, and the Saskatchewan River crossing eight miles to the west where crews were hard at work for the construction of the bridge to carry the river.

During the summer of 1904, grade had been built as far as Edmonton and during 1905 from near until mid-December the steel was laid to that point.

This required the co-operation of several large crews of men serving the different requirements; a temporary pile and timber bridge was built across the river, and then the main bridge material, crewed, and track laying operations commenced on the south side of the river.

The track laying crews included a 200-man crew organized to handle the steel rails from 10 feet away until placed and spiked on the ties.

The ties were hauled from a string of five cars.
By seven teams of mules and horses dumping their loads of ties on the grade, rounded where they were placed and spaced ahead of the advancing steel. Two trains of steel and ties came up from the material yard per day; the first arriving between 6 and 7 a.m., and the second about 1 p.m. The work of track laying was continued until the trains were unloaded.

If necessary, two or three team drivers unloading the ties and dumping them on the grade, see the managing or "boss" jobs were occupied by very outstanding men for difficult, and new situations were very frequently gathering requiring a bit of a high order to cope with them and keep the track laying coming smoothly, and I think a description of them would be appropriate.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: WILLIAM HOWSE
2. Your address: CARRAGANA, SASK
3. Date: Dec. 1962
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): MONMOUTH, ENGLAND
5. What was your father's name and occupation?: J.H. HOWSE SADLER
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): May 1904
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: Miami, Manitoba from Aug 1903 till May 1904
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," "I was in my teens," etc.): 30 years
9. What were your reasons for coming West?: I had been apprenticed to Electrical Work, finishing that period in 1903 & worked in London but following the end of the Boer War I became one of a large number of unemployed in Northwich, Northwich when worked fifty thousand lost their jobs in one week. This caused me to leave & come to Canada seek work.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?): Through other people and the intensive advertising put on by the Government.

   - Winnipeg, Manitoba from Aug. 1903 till May 1904
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I" was a small child," "I was in my teens," etc.) 20 years
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   - I had been apprenticed to Electrical Work, finishing that part in 1904. I worked in London for (following the war) the Board of Trade. I became an electrician in Northam (then known as Northam) last claim. I was in one week. You can see me to hear me come to Canada's work.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)
    - Through other people and the information being put out by the Government.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   They were against my coming, but I was young & anxious to experience a little of the world.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   By myself, but made travelling friends quickly.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   S.S. Corinthian (Allen Line) to Montreal via Colonist train to Winnipeg C.P.R.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
   A lot of the passengers were young Electricians like myself & the journey was very pleasant and without incident.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   Battleford neighborhood, working on roads & bridges on the Saskatoon Trail, in tents.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   48 miles West of Battleford, on Cut Knife Plain.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   All my time until settling on Homestead was at various outdoor jobs on Road or Railroad building & bridges including C.N.R. bridge 8 miles west of Battleford.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
   On farms in Manitoba.
   (Settled on my homestead) in 1906, occasionally going away to earn funds to carry on, & buy needed equipment.

They were against it at first, but they came to like it.

S.S. Courthian (Allen Line) to Montreal via Clover Train to Winnipeg C.P.R.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

Myself, a little nervous was very pleasant and without incident.

Battleford neighborhood, writing on ready bridges on the Saskatchewan Trail in tent.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

All my time until settling on Homestead 1 mile west of railway station (C.W.R. Bridge 8 miles west of Battleford)

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

On farms in Manitoba, (settled on homestead) in 1906, occasionally going away to earn funds to carry on buying needed equipment.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   Not too often, a few times per year, but letters were very welcome.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.
   I was married in Winnipeg in fall 1920, through accident & World war II happened.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?
   I don't think so.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.
   [Handwritten text not legible]

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
   Quite a few, would almost fill a book.
   I served in Canadian artillery in World War I & returning back filled on land North of Prairie River on Bush land, it was a tougher proposition but we made out, our second son farms the land, our five children have made good with good homes & families.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
   Mostly on outside work, my probably longest job was construction of C.N.R. from Battleford to Edmonton from May to Dec. 1905. This was a great experience & met some very outstanding men.
   Perhaps a description of this work might be of historical value, conditions & work were very severe.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make? In 1930 or about that time, Ford Model T, Coach.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home? First Battleford, then Paynton, then Unity, finally Cut Knife. After the war it was Prairie River & then Carriagama.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.) Our trade town came as the Railroad were built, C.N.R. through Paynton & Battleford, then Unity, when Grand Trunk Pacific was built, then branch line to Cut Knife from Wilkie C.P.R.

29. How often did you shop in the early days? As needs arose, a week, a month or longer.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays? Probably during war times.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it? It was installed in my house while I was away in the War & charges for unused service.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision? Expected to stay if things turned out satisfactory, I did not mind pioneer conditions. People varied but on the whole were friendly, strict a good code of honesty.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Yes, families often moved away because good land was hard to find out there. Otherwise, work likely had to be done.

This applied to the stay in Cut Knife area.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

In this district, very few of the original settlers stayed long enough to prove up; the conditions were too severe, there were no roads, farms, or facilities.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Not much. See first school volunteer organizer for a few social needs.

This applies to the members of our family.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district, mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combining, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

Not much, but a few firsts: first gasoline engine used for wood sawing & grinding.

First radio, home built one tube headphones set, but a wonder to all visitors.

(School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name, (2) origin and meaning of the name, (3) date of its adoption, (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. 9. What was life like in your community during the Great Depression? How did people cope with the economic hardships?

Life was very difficult during the Great Depression. Many families struggled to make ends meet. People worked long hours for low wages and often had to rely on government assistance programs. Despite these challenges, communities came together to support each other and find ways to survive.
